title: Does the human brain produce consciousness through quantum mechanical processes (i.e., is it a quantum mechanical system)? - Quora

response.answer_text: Conventional answer: quantum mechanics can’t explain the human mind. Despite the universal validity of the superposition principle, we see a live cat or a dead cat, never a live-and-dead cat superposition. Thermally-induced decoherence "destroys" (i.e. scrambles to the environment in a thermodynamically irreversible way) superpositions of distributed neuronal feature-processors in the warm, wet CNS too rapidly to support phenomenal binding into perceptual objects (cf. Maximilian Schlosshauer, "The quantum-to-classical transition and decoherence": http://arxiv.org/pdf/1404.2635v1.pdf). Not least, the dynamical timescale for quantum-coherent neuronal feature-binding is wrong – femtoseconds or less versus (we assume) scores of milliseconds. In consequence, even if some form of panpsychism is true, the existence of phenomenally-bound perceptual objects populating our classical world-simulations remains a fathomless mystery. Unconventional answer: only quantum mechanics can explain the mind. Phenomenal binding of distributed neuronal feature-processors into perceptual objects is classically impossible. The universal validity of the superposition principle in QM explains why we see classical cats in phenomenal world-simulations described by an approximation of classical mechanics. Recall Bertrand Russell's oft-quoted remark that one only ever sees the inside of one's own head. If membrane-bound neurons in the CNS were discrete, decohered classical objects, as we naively assume, then packs of neurons would at most be micro-experiential zombies: mere patterns of what William James christened "mind-dust" (cf. Phil Goff, Why panpsychism doesn't help explain consciousness). For 86 billion-odd distributed neuronal "pixels" of experience [colour-, motion-, shape-, edge- (etc) detectors] could no more create a phenomenally-bound classical cat-percept than 320 million skull-bound American minds could intercommunicate to create a unitary pan-continental cat-experience. Classical physics can’t explain local or global phenomenal binding. By contrast, quantum physics potentially delivers a perfect structural match between the phenomenology of our minds and the formalism of QFT – confounding David Chalmers’ dualism:  Can we put these two rival conjectures to the test? Yes, in principle! Unfortunately, armchair physicists probably underestimate the technical challenges to creating and experimentally manipulating in vitro "Schrödinger’s neurons" superpositions (cf. physicalism. com: an experimentally testable conjecture). Yet unless the unitary dynamics of QM breaks down in neuronal networks (unlikely!), fleeting neuronal superpositions must exist. What’s in question is whether decoherence in the CNS is too fast and uncontrollable for selection pressure on these neuronal superpositions ever to have got to work. My best guess – no more – is that such a molecular matter-wave interferometry experiment will confirm that organic minds have been quantum computers for over 540 million years. For a nice non-technical overview of the decoherence program in post-Everett QM, see John Campbell’s review of Zurek’s “Quantum Darwinism”:http://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1001/1001.0745.pdf

At the time of this writing, 3 other responses have been written. One says “Sure”. One says “No”. To break the tie, the last one says “Maybe”. Intelligence and quantum mechanics both have mathematically intriguing properties: consciousness, intuition, mixed states, interference, no-cloning, and more, but it's not clear how they might or might not be related. The no-cloning theorem (related to the uncertainty principle) dictates that there is more quantum information in any brain than can be replicated in a perfect copy, but that doesn't mean that the lost details are crucial to thought in any way. Likewise, intuition (for example, understanding why 1+1=2 without someone teaching you) is impossible to achieve perfectly with any algorithm, which might suggest a depth to intelligence that can't be simulated with classical physics, but who says that conscious intuition is perfect to begin with? Even if intelligence arises just from interactions of neurons and neurotransmitters, the mush of classical particles that makes up any brain is still governed by quantum mechanics, so we've got that going for us, which is nice. Scott Aaronson’s work is probably the best resource to fact-check and go deeper: Shtetl-Optimized

YES. Below I briefly explain why. To be fair, you should first know that most experts in neuroscience and physics who have considered this question would say what Steve Zara said: “No. The brain is a vast collection of neural networks which operate through electrical and chemical interactions. There is no place in that for any quantum-mechanical strangeness.” Temperature objection: Many scientists believe that it is implausible that a macroscopic quantum state could survive in a warm brain. This opinion is typically based on calculations in simple models that assume thermodynamic equilibrium in brain tissue (Tegmark 2000). But an older simple model (Frohlich) demonstrates how energy flow through a system (i.e. steady-state metabolism, not at thermal equilibrium) of molecular dipoles can organize it into stable coherent states even at high temperatures. So in my opinion a quantum substrate for consciousness in the brain is not ruled out. But why would one consider such an “exotic” hypothesis when current understanding of neural dynamics seems to account for a wide range of behavioral and cognitive phenomena? It is very popular to deride theoretical arguments, but here is a simple argument that motivates the idea that consciousness requires a quantum physical description. Our states of consciousness are intrinsically unified; they are irreducible wholes. But there are no irreducible wholes in classical physics. Really. Quantum physics on the other hand describes the dynamics of irreducible wholes, because that’s what quantum states are. Thus the quantum brain or quantum consciousness or quantum mind approach has the potential to solve the “phenomenal binding problem” at a fundamental level. This should not be dismissed lightly because synchrony in a classical brain model (a la Singer) cannot do this (I said why above), despite protests you may hear from well educated people. One can also note that despite impressive successes classical neural network theory has not yet managed to account for the full range of human cognitive abilities, even if we recklessly decide to neglect consciousness. Yes (classical) computers can beat us at face recognition and Go now, but current models simply do not capture the flexibility of our “common sense.” Quantum computation in a brain could give it significant advantages over a classical brain (e.g. Quantum Associative Memory). Quantum physics is not “exotic” or “strange” to Nature; it is Nature. A variety of “circumstantial” experimental evidence is consistent with the possibility I am arguing for, that a macroscopic quantum state in the brain underlies our consciousness and mind. For example, Context effects produced by question orders reveal quantum nature of human judgments. From the biophysical side, ultraweak light radiation emitted by all living tissue (“biophotons”) has been shown by Popp et al to exhibit a non-equilibrium distribution demonstrating the existence of an underlying coherent state.Such leakage of coherent light radiation is predicted by certain quantum models of memory and consciousness (Del Giudice, Vitiello). Aside from the temperature objection addressed above, another common objection to the hypothesis that a quantum process underlies consciousness, is the assertion that “there is no place” for quantum effects in the brain. This attitude stems from familiarity with the deterministic Hodgkin-Huxley equations which govern neural dynamics like Newton’s Laws in physics. If these equations determine everything neurons do, how could there be a role for some additional quantum ghost? But synaptic transmission among neurons in the central nervous system is extremely “noisy” or random or “unreliable.” In other words, synaptic transmission in the brain is probabilistic, and the transmission probabilities vary with time. We do not necessarily know every factor that can affect synaptic transmission probability at each synapse from moment to moment. This apparent randomness represents a “place” where a hypothetical quantum state could interact with the well-known neural machinery to guide adaptive behavior. As a concrete example, the theory of Hameroff and Penrose posits a collective quantum state in brain microtubules. The microtubule state could condition the state of the photon field inside microtubules, which in turn could modulate synaptic transmission probabilities via liquid-crystal actin molecules that reside near the synaptic junction (the microtubules tend to be “aimed” down neuronal axons toward the synapse). This is analogous to how liquid-crystal gates function in optical computers. This is one specific example to demonstrate that the brain’s neural networks are not completely determined classical machines even in the mainstream description, so one can reasonably consider how a hypothetical additional factor—the quantum conscious process—might interact with the known neural machinery.

Probably/maybe, going with the intent of your question (which seems to be something like ‘is quantum mechanics a useful and/or essential tool/perspective for understanding the nature of the human mind?’). But we won't/can't know until we make a better first guess at what ‘human mind intelligence’ is. (A little bit of ‘chicken or the egg’ going on here, necessarily…) It is plausible to frame ‘mind intelligence’ as an emergent property, but this proposition remains void of meaning until you postulate a causal mechanism (and not merely a correlation, which is what the ‘info processing complexity’ theory does) or theory, or any explanation whatsoever, for WHY this particular property emerges. Counter example: electricity ‘emerges’ from the activity of electrons, so to speak, but we can explain why, so it is useful to frame this as an emergent property. Not so for the ‘human mind intelligence’/consciousness…. no one has a clue about what causes this… If you want a ‘fun’ intro to the sheer magnitude of this challenge, read Frank Herbert's Destination Void (1966). Also, check out Piero Scaruffi’s extensive multidisciplinary literature review, which provides a helpful condensation of many different scholarly perspectives from many different cultures. Andrew Lynch's post in 'Hard' Consciousness

I'm emphatically not an expert in this field, but I find it interesting and have read a lot of books and talked to a lot of friends and relatives in various scientific specialties about it. From what I understand, it's not inconceivable that quantum computing might be involved in the production of consciousness, but it's not very likely. To keep entangled particles from decohering, you need to keep them very isolated from other particles and forces, either with magnetic traps or very low temperatures. The brain is a warm, wet, chemically and electrically active environment, terrible for quantum computing. Also, it doesn't seem like you need to invoke quantum computing to understand consciousness, for a couple of reasons. First of all, plain old chemistry is perfectly adequate to produce the full complexity of the brain's activities. Secondly, the brain probably isn't a computer at all; it has no top-down organizational structure. The brain is more of an ecosystem where certain synaptic connections compete for metabolic resources. Consciousness emerges from this competition, as synapses form networks of networks of networks, eventually building up recursive representations of the brain's activities to itself.

It has been suggested that the microtubules in cells could perform quantum computation and that this could help explain how single cell amoebas can react with incredible sophistication to their environment. It is humorous to note that that it took a long time to discover microtubules existed because the standard method of preparing cells to be examined under a microscope dissolved the microtubules. Just off the top of my head I think that there is some interest in the connection between the fact that anesthesia tends to dissolve microtubules and the fact that it causes one to lose consciousness, but I'd definitely cross check that. That said, I don't believe quantum computation in necessary to explain consciousness.  I do have one personal observation though. In quantum mechanics there are always significant ramifications for when particles or systems are indistinguishable. I believe consciousness innately must be indistinguishable regardless of the individual or entity experiencing it. I think consciousness may end up being considered a type of singularity in physics, not to imply any connection to black holes. I have no clue to what the ramifications of these ideas are, but I suspect they are valid concerns.

Yes, even in the interpretations of quantum theory that posit hard determinism. Hard determinism, even though it rejects all ontological randomness, is compatible with alternative possibilities. It does not preclude the power to "do otherwise", so does not contradict our belief in conscious freedom of choice. Even under hard determinism the set of conditions which specify an observed system is not adequate to determine which event will be observed. The conditions define instead a range of possible events from among which some particular event will be observed. When an observer exercises freedom, by his act of choice he is adding a factor not supplied by the observed system and is thus himself determining what will occur. That he does so is known only to himself. From the outside one can see in his act only the working of physical law. It is the inner knowledge that he is in fact doing what he intends to do that tells the observer himself that he is free. The outcome is neither random nor determined only by the observed system. We must still however accept that the future is at all times determined- not solely by the observed system but by the observer acting in conjunction with the system. See also: Greg Sunderland's answer to How would you explain the Higgs boson particle to a seven-year old?

We don't have evidence to support the assumption that anything 'produces' consciousness. Tononi & Koch's Integrated information theory is arguably the leading theory of consciousness at the moment, and it concludes that consciousness is likely an irreducible factor in nature, as a form of panpsychism associated with the integration of information. Hameroff and Penrose's Orchestrated Objective Reduction theory also suggests that rather than the brain 'producing' consciousness through QM processes, quantum processes themselves are already consciousness. Both of these suggest that brains are simply an example of the form that one type of consciousness expresses and that consciousness itself is intrinsic in the cosmos.

My view: Quantum Mechanics is irrelevant to free will.  If you think that free will needs freedom from the ability of someone to predict what you do, then quantum mechanics doesn't help because it happens on such an incredibly tiny scale it has no relevance to how you make your decisions.  Your decisions, according to biology, are the result of the states of brain cells, and brain cell states are vastly bigger and longer-lived than quantum effects.  So, quantum mechanics is nowhere near a large enough gap in physics (assuming it is a gap) for unpredictability to have an influence on mental events. If, like me, you believe that free will is not about predictability, but freedom from other influences than your own wishes, then quantum mechanics is of no consequence anyway.

It doesn't, but it's possible that it's involved. Penrose and Hameroff have been focusing for some years now on a model called "Orch-OR" to handle wave-function collapse. It's still a bit out-there, but what they did prove recently was that microtubules in neurons could act like finite-state automata due to quantum effects, and could lead to stabilized long-time period coherent states. Here - have a paper which contains a lot more details, and is well worth wading through: Consciousness in the universe: A review of the ‘Orch OR’ theory

No. The human brain most likely does not produce consciousness through quantum mechanical processes. I am going to repost Leo C. Stein's excellent answer here .  You might be interested to look at an actual computation of quantum decoherence times in the brain: http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/99... -- the punchline of this calculation is that the timescale for quantum decoherence in the brain is in the ballpark of 10−20−10−13s, which is extremely short compared to the dynamical timescale of 0.001−0.1s. This means thatcomputations in the brain are classical, not quantum mechanical.

I think the short answer is 'no'. If you think free will means 'unpredictability' (as Steve Zara suggested), then I'd say, "OK". (Neurons and synapses are on a scale where quantum superposition could have an effect; Roger Penrose is enamored with this idea.) But: I don't think unpredictability has much to do with free will, and neither do most philosophers. It's more about the causal connections between mental processes and actions, whether you're *determined* by causes outside your control to act as you do. You might think QM gives a 'yes' answer in this case, since not only is it unpredictable (sometimes), that unpredictability is the result of fundamentally chancy events. But... all this means is that, if QM explains your actions (or the will that caused them), that those things themselves are uncaused, and in an important sense, arbitrary! Check out Yariv Hastilow's links for more.

I think the opposite question would make more sense - Do quantum effects interfere with free will? A deterministic universe would mean that each decision we make is based entirely on the state of our own mind (brain) and the rest of the universe at a given time. I don't see how you could get more free than that. The interference of something not dependent on either your mind or the rest of the universe, whether that thing is God or randomness caused by quantum unpredictability, can only reduce your ability to make the decisions that your mind "intends".

Quantum mechanics doesn't study the mind and really has nothing to say about areas of study above the scale that it functions on. A brain has about 100 billion neurons. Each of those has about 10 billion atoms, which is the scale that quantum mechanics studies. At that scale, quantum mechanics doesn't have anything to say that wasn't already discovered by classical mechanics and electrodynamics. The weight of the probabilities in the QM world gets turned into statistics that form the laws of physics we all understand intuitively.

I would not say it is due to quantum mechanics, but that quantum mechanics enables the existence of non-trivial kinds of free will. I say "non-trivial" because there are actually quite a few different kinds of "free will" that people have talked about over the centuries, some of them corresponding closely to the popular notions, some of them being far less interesting, even 'trivial'. See Free Will (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy), The Problem of Evil and Compatibilism (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy) for the gory details.

Water is wet, but neither hydrogen or oxygen are wet. So it is with consciousness. While consciousness requires quantum mechanics to express itself, it cannot be simply reduced to quantum mechanics. However, we can get a better understanding of how consciousness works by understanding quantum mechanics. This is exactly how we get insight into the properties of water by looking at how hydrogen and oxygen bond.
